articles.headline: U.S. Sets Higher Fuel Efficiency Standards
articles.snippet: The rules, first proposed last year, would require new cars and trucks to average 54.5 miles per gallon in combined city and highway driving by 2025.
articles.abstract: The rules, first proposed last year, would require new cars and trucks to average 54.5 miles per gallon in combined city and highway driving by 2025.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The Obama administration issued on Tuesday the final version of new rules that require automakers to nearly double the average fuel economy of new cars and trucks by 2025.

articles.headline: Central Banker Facing a Test
articles.snippet: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, will be under pressure to provide details of his plan to shore up the euro zone’s weaker member nations by buying their bonds.
articles.abstract: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, will be under pressure to provide details of his plan to shore up the euro zone’s weaker member nations by buying their bonds.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, has helped the euro zone survive August. But can he save September?

articles.headline: Many Hands Patch Together Syrian Rebels’ Arsenal
articles.snippet: A network of tradesmen and businesses have helped to piece together an arsenal to counter the Assad government’s army.
articles.abstract: A network of tradesmen and businesses have helped to piece together an arsenal to counter the Assad government’s army.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAL RIFAAT, Syria — As the midsummer sun blazed over this partially deserted Syrian city one recent afternoon, two young men appeared in a pickup truck in an alley near several auto repair workshops. Protruding from the truck’s bed was a steel pipe about three feet long and two and a half inches wide, resting on a simple frame.

articles.headline: Unleashing the Campaign Contributions of Corporations
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court has removed most limits to corporate political donations, but researchers have found that such money has not had much influence in past elections.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court has removed most limits to corporate political donations, but researchers have found that such money has not had much influence in past elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: Way back in February of this year,  more than two-thirds of Californians believed raising more money from tobacco companies to finance cancer research was a good idea. That was before industry money kicked in.

articles.headline: Victims’ Sons in Tough Fight for Redress After China Rail Crash
articles.snippet: Two Chinese-American brothers’ odyssey to retrieve their parents’ bodies and gain compensation for a deadly high-speed railroad crash highlighted the workings of an unbending government agency in China.
articles.abstract: Two Chinese-American brothers’ odyssey to retrieve their parents’ bodies and gain compensation for a deadly high-speed railroad crash highlighted the workings of an unbending government agency in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Henry Cao has stark memories of the moment the high-speed train he was riding rear-ended another last summer in the eastern city of Wenzhou: the pleasantly hypnotic rocking that gave way to a jolt he likened to an earthquake, followed by blackness and the sensation of falling as the car plummeted 100 feet off a viaduct.

articles.headline: New York State Is Investigating Energy Drink Makers
articles.snippet: New York is looking at whether the makers of energy drinks are misleading consumers about how much caffeine the drinks contain and the health risks they could pose.
articles.abstract: New York is looking at whether the makers of energy drinks are misleading consumers about how much caffeine the drinks contain and the health risks they could pose.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general has subpoenaed three large makers of so-called energy drinks as part of an investigation into whether the companies are misleading consumers about how much caffeine the drinks contain and the health risks they could pose.

articles.headline: Nomination Secure, Romney Pitch Starts
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney’s wife, Ann, took the lead in trying to shape perceptions of her husband, hailing him as a strong and steadfast family man whom Americans could trust to help rebuild the economy.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney’s wife, Ann, took the lead in trying to shape perceptions of her husband, hailing him as a strong and steadfast family man whom Americans could trust to help rebuild the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Mitt Romney, a former governor of Massachusetts who has aspired to reach the White House since his father first sought the office four decades ago, was nominated by the Republican Party here on Tuesday as its choice to become the 45th president of the United States.

articles.headline: Fast Rise Built With Discipline
articles.snippet: Paul D. Ryan’s uncanny ability to develop relationships with like-minded conservatives while he worked on Capitol Hill helped lay the groundwork for his ascension to vice-presidential candidate.
articles.abstract: Paul D. Ryan’s uncanny ability to develop relationships with like-minded conservatives while he worked on Capitol Hill helped lay the groundwork for his ascension to vice-presidential candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the early 1990s, Tortilla Coast, a popular Capitol Hill watering hole, was staffed by ambitious young men and women flinging Tex-Mex and margaritas at patrons whose jobs in the nearby House and Senate office buildings they not so secretly coveted.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Isaac Drenches Gulf Coast and High Water Cuts Off Many
articles.snippet: Downgraded to a tropical storm on Wednesday, Isaac brought its own distinctive mode of destruction to the Gulf Coast seven years after Hurricane Katrina.
articles.abstract: Downgraded to a tropical storm on Wednesday, Isaac brought its own distinctive mode of destruction to the Gulf Coast seven years after Hurricane Katrina.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Seven years to the day that Hurricane Katrina and levee failures unleashed a deluge of devastation on the Gulf Coast, Hurricane Isaac brought its own distinctive mode of destruction on Wednesday, drenching the coast not with a quick blow but with an unremitting smothering.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Kim Severson

articles.headline: Economy Still Stuck in Low Gear
articles.snippet: The Commerce Department raised its estimate of growth in the second quarter slightly, but the economy remained weak by historical standards.
articles.abstract: The Commerce Department raised its estimate of growth in the second quarter slightly, but the economy remained weak by historical standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: Government data released Wednesday suggested the economy continued to muddle along at a subdued pace, highlighting the pressure on Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, to come up with bolder policy prescriptions Friday when he delivers a widely anticipated speech in Jackson Hole, Wyo.

articles.headline: Japan Strives to Go Nuclear-Free
articles.snippet: As the country moves to cut back on nuclear power after the disaster in Fukushima, it is finding that the cost of abandoning its reactors may be too high for some big utilities to shoulder.
articles.abstract: As the country moves to cut back on nuclear power after the disaster in Fukushima, it is finding that the cost of abandoning its reactors may be too high for some big utilities to shoulder.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — As Japan moves to cut back on nuclear power after last year’s disaster in Fukushima, it is running into a harsh economic reality: the cost of immediately abandoning its nuclear reactors may be too high for some big utilities to shoulder.
